a: It is not appropriate to leave this man by the side of the road in order to preserve your leather upholstery.

title: Country Road
a: The man's life is more important than the leather upholstery in your car. If you leave him by the side of the road, he may die.

A young boy is visiting his grandmother for the weekend. Usually she gives 
 him a gift of a few dollars when he arrives, but this time she doesn’t. He asks her why not and she says something about how he doesn’t write her as many letters as he used to. Later that night, she makes her tea, and the dissolved pills make her sick. In the morning she is dead. a: No, it was not appropriate for the boy to put pills in his grandmother's teapot.

 and the ship has to be abandoned. The lifeboats are carrying many more people than they were designed to carry. The lifeboat you’re in is sitting dangerously low in the water—a few inches lower and it will sink. The seas start to get rough, and the boat begins to fill with water. If nothing is done it will sink before the rescue boats arrive and everyone on board will die. However, there is an injured person who will not survive in any case. If you throw that person overboard the boat will stay afloat and the remaining passengers will be saved. Is it appropriate for you to throw this person overboard in order to save the lives of the remaining passengers?
title: Lifeboat 2
a: It is not appropriate to throw this person overboard.

question: Why?
title: Lifeboat 2
a: The reason is that it would be an act of murder. The person in question is injured and will not survive in any case, so throwing them overboard would be an act of killing them. Even though it would be done in order to save the lives of the remaining passengers, it would still be an act of murder and would be morally wrong.

question:

 is about to go to jail and that in his last forty-eight hours of freedom he plans to infect as many people as possible with HIV. You know him well enough to know that he is telling the truth and that he has access to many potential victims. You happen to know that he has a very strong allergy to poppy seeds. If he eats even one he will go into convulsions and have to be hospitalized. for at least forty-eight hours. Is it appropriate for you to cause this man to have a serious allergy attack in order to prevent him from spreading HIV?
title: Preventing the Spread 2
a: There is no easy answer to this question. On the one hand, it may be morally wrong to deliberately make someone sick, even if it is in order to prevent a greater evil. On the other hand, if this man is allowed to go around infecting people with HIV, that could lead to a great deal of suffering and death. In the end, it may be up to the individual waiter to decide what to do in this situation.

question: Why?
title: Preventing the Spread 2
a: The reason why this situation is difficult to judge is because there are two different sets of moral principles at play. On the one hand, there is the principle that it is wrong to deliberately harm another person, even if that harm is done in order to prevent a greater harm from occurring. On the other hand, there is the principle that it is sometimes morally permissible to cause harm to another person if that is the only way to prevent a greater harm from occurring.
